list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Find the number of ways in which twelve different baseball cards can be
given to Emily, Harry, John and Olivia, if Emily is to receive $5$
cards, Harry is to receive $3$ cards, John is to receive $3$ cards and
Olivia is to receive $1$ card (in that order).
list.markScheme:
Choose $5$ from $12$ baseball cards for Emily, then choose $3$ from $7$
remaining cards for Harry, then choose $3$ from $4$ remaining cards for
John and give the last card which is left to Olivia.
Hence the total number of ways is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\binom{12}{5}\binom{7}{3}\binom{4}{3}\binom{1}{1} &= \dfrac{12!}{5!\cdot\cancel{7!}}\cdot\dfrac{\cancel{7!}}{3!\cdot\cancel{4!}}\cdot\dfrac{\cancel{4!}}{3!\cdot1!}\cdot 1  \\[6pt]
&= \dfrac{12!}{5!\cdot3!\cdot3!\cdot1!} \\[15pt]
&\answer{= 110\hspace{0.15em}880}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Tyler needs to decide the order in which to schedule $11$ exams for his
school. Two of these exams are Chemistry ($1$ SL and $1$ HL).
Find the number of different ways Tyler can schedule the $11$ exams
given that the two Chemistry subjects must not be consecutive.
list.markScheme:
Let $n$ be the number of different ways in which the $11$ exams can be
scheduled such that the two Chemistry subjects are not consecutive. To
find $n$, subtract from $11!$ the number of possible ways to order the
$11$ exams such that the two Chemistry subjects are consecutive.

$$
\begin{aligned}
n &= 11! - 9!\times\binom{2}{2}\times2!\times\binom{10}{1}\times1!  \\[6pt]
&= 11! - 9!\times2!\times10 \\[12pt]
&\answer{\approx 3.27\times10^{7}}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content: A police department has $4$ male and $7$ female officers. A special group of $5$ officers is to be assembled for an undercover operation. - Determine how many possible groups can be chosen. [2] - Determine how many groups can be formed consisting of $2$ males and $3$ $\text{females.}$[2] - Determine how many groups can be formed consisting of at least one male. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We choose $5$ people from $4+7 = 11$ males and females.
Hence the number of possible groups is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \binom{11}{5} &= \dfrac{11!}{5!\cdot6!} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 462}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We choose $2$ officers from $4$ males and then we choose $3$ more
officers from $7$ females. Hence the number of groups consisting of
$3$ males and $2$ females is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} \binom{4}{2}\binom{7}{3} &= \dfrac{4!}{2!\cdot2!}\cdot\dfrac{7!}{3!\cdot4!} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 210}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The number of groups consisting of $0$ males and $5$ females is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} \binom{4}{0}\binom{7}{5} &= \dfrac{4!}{0!\cdot4!}\cdot\dfrac{7!}{5!\cdot2!} \\[6pt]
  &= 21\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the number of groups consisting of at
least $1$ male is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  462 - 21 &= \hspace{0.525em}\answer{441} \hspace{1.65em}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 4
list.content: A school basketball team of $5$ students is selected from $8$ boys and $4$ girls. - Determine how many possible teams can be chosen. [2] - Determine how many teams can be formed consisting of $3$ boys and $2$ girls? [2] - Determine how many teams can be formed consisting of at most $3$ girls? [2]
list.markScheme:
- We choose $5$ students from $8+4 = 12$ boys and girls.
Hence the number of possible teams is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \binom{12}{5} &= \dfrac{12!}{5!\cdot7!} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 792}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We choose $3$ students from $8$ boys and then we choose $2$ more
students from $4$ girls. Hence the number of teams consisting of $3$
boys and $2$ girls is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} \binom{8}{3}\binom{4}{2} &= \dfrac{8!}{3!\cdot5!}\cdot\dfrac{4!}{2!\cdot2!} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 336}\end{aligned}
  $$

- A team of $5$ students can either have $0,1,2,3$ or $4$ girls. The
number of teams consisting of $1$ boy and $4$ girls is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \binom{8}{1}\binom{4}{4} = 8 \hspace{3.5em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
number of teams consisting of at most $3$ girls is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  792 - 8 &= \hspace{0.525em}\answer{784} \hspace{1.25em}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: In an art museum, there are 8 different paintings by Picasso, 5 different paintings by Van Gogh, and 3 different paintings by Rembrandt. The curator of the museum wants to hold an exhibition in a hall that can only display a maximum of 7 paintings at a time. The curator wants to include at least two paintings from each artist in the exhibition. - Given that 7 paintings will be displayed, determine how many ways they can be selected. [4] - Find the probability that more Rembrandt paintings will be selected than Picasso paintings or Van Gogh paintings. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Given that there must be at least 2 paintings by each artist, there are three cases to consider:
  
  - 3 Picasso, 2 Van Gogh, 2 Rembrandt
  - 2 Picasso, 3 Van Gogh, 2 Rembrandt
  - 2 Picasso, 2 Van Gogh, 3 Rembrandt

  Let $k_1$ be the total number of combinations from option 1, $k_2$ the total from option 2 and $k_3$ the total from option 3.
  In the first case, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k_1 &= {}^8C_3 \times {}^5C_2 \times {}^3C_2 \\[6pt]
      &= 1680
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In the second case, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k_2 &= {}^8C_2 \times {}^5C_3 \times {}^3C_2 \\[6pt]
      &= 840
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In the third case, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k_3 &= {}^8C_2 \times {}^5C_2 \times {}^3C_3 \\[6pt]
      &= 280
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Overall, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= k_1 + k_2 + k_3 \\[6pt]
      &= 1680 + 840 + 280
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In total there are $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{2800}\hspace{0.525em}$ ways in which the paintings can be selected.
- For there to be more Rembrandt paintings selected than Picasso or Van Gogh, there must be 3 by Rembrandt, 2 by Picasso and 2 by Van Gogh. From part (a), there are 280 possible combinations that fit this criteria, and 2800 combinations overall. Therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      \mathrm{P}(3\mathrm{R}\,2\mathrm{P}\,2\mathrm{V}) &= \dfrac{280}{2800} \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{-5.5em}\tcbhighmath{\mathrm{P}(3\mathrm{R}\,2\mathrm{P}\,2\mathrm{V}) = \dfrac{1}{10}} 
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Peter needs to decide the order in which to schedule $14$ exams for his
school. Two of these exams are Chemistry ($1$ SL and $1$ HL).
Find the number of different ways Peter can schedule the $14$ exams
given that the two Chemistry subjects must not be consecutive.
list.markScheme:
Let $n$ be the number of different ways in which the $14$ exams can be
scheduled such that the two Chemistry subjects are not consecutive. To
find $n$, subtract from $14!$ the number of possible ways to order the
$14$ exams such that the two Chemistry subjects are consecutive.

$$
\begin{aligned}
n &= 14! - 12!\times\binom{2}{2}\times2!\times\binom{13}{1}\times1!  \\[6pt]
&= 14! - 12!\times2!\times13 \\[12pt]
&\answer{\approx 7.47\times10^{10}}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: An arts and crafts store is offering a special package on personalized keychains. The store has a selection of $6$ distinct types of charms. Customers can personalize their keychains with between 1 and $3$ distinct charms from the selection mentioned above. Determine how many ways a customer can personalize a keychain if - The order of the selections is important. [3] - The order of the selections is not important. [3]
list.markScheme:
- A customer can select either 1, 2 or 3 unique charms, all of which are different. Therefore we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= {}^6P_1 + {}^6P_2 + {}^6P_3
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Using the formula for permutations, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= \dfrac{6!}{5!} + \dfrac{6!}{4!} + \dfrac{6!}{3!} \\[10pt]
      &= \dfrac{6\times\cancel{5!}}{\cancel{5!}} + \dfrac{6\times5\times\cancel{4!}}{\cancel{4!}} + \dfrac{6\times5\times4\times\cancel{3!}}{\cancel{3!}} \\[10pt]
      &= 6 + 30 + 120
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In total there are $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{156}\hspace{0.525em}$ ways in which a customer can personalize a keychain if the order is important.
- A customer can select either 1, 2 or 3 unique charms, all of which are different. Therefore we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= {}^6C_1 + {}^6C_2 + {}^6C_3
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Using the formula for combinations, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= \dfrac{6!}{1!5!} + \dfrac{6!}{2!4!} + \dfrac{6!}{3!3!} \\[10pt]
      &= \dfrac{6\times\cancel{5!}}{1\times\cancel{5!}} + \dfrac{6\times5\times\cancel{4!}}{2\times\cancel{4!}} + \dfrac{\cancel{6}\times5\times4\times\cancel{3!}}{\cancel{3!}\times\cancel{3!}} \\[10pt]
      &= 6 + 15 + 20
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In total there are $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{41}\hspace{0.525em}$ ways in which a customer can personalize a keychain if the order is not important.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Ten students are to be arranged in a new chemistry lab. The chemistry lab is set out in two rows of five desks as shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e170a0fe-977c-4bd7-b87e-9e1886187985/images/f8681d28-d470-4e1b-8738-223f58a3ae4c/42b953ec648c17bd92a6ba9406f0ca05241c501c.svg) - Find the number of ways the ten students may be arranged in the lab. [1] Two of the students, Hugo and Leo, were noticed to talk to each other during previous lab sessions. - Find the number of ways the students may be arranged if Hugo and Leo must sit so that one is directly behind the other. For example, Desk $1$ and Desk $6$. [2] - Find the number of ways the students may be arranged if Hugo and Leo must not sit next to each other in the same row. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{10! = 3\hspace{0.15em}628\hspace{0.15em}800}$
- Hugo and Leo may be arranged in the lab first in $(5)(2) = 10$ ways
so that one is directly behind the other. Then the rest of the
students may be arranged in $8! = 40\hspace{0.15em}320$ ways.
In this case, the number of ways the ten students may be
arranged in the lab is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{(10)(8!) = 403\hspace{0.15em}200}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Hugo and Leo may be arranged in the lab first in $(8)(2) = 16$ ways
so that they sit next to each other. Then the rest of the students
may be arranged in $8! = 40\hspace{0.15em}320$ ways.
In this case, the number of ways the ten students may be
arranged in the lab is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (16)(8!) = 645\hspace{0.15em}120\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if Hugo and
Leo must not sit next to each other, the number of ways is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.5em} 10! - (16)(8!) &= 3\hspace{0.15em}628\hspace{0.15em}800 - 645\hspace{0.15em}120 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2\hspace{0.15em}983\hspace{0.15em}680}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 9
list.content: A professor and five of his students attend a talk given in a lecture series. They have a row of 8 seats to themselves. Find the number of ways the professor and his students can sit if - the professor and his students sit together. [3] - the students decide to sit at least one seat apart from their professor. [4]
list.markScheme:
- We can consider the 8 seats as three "blocks", where one block consists of the 6 adjacent seats that the professor and his students occupy, and the other two blocks are the remaining two single seats. There are three possible arrangements of these blocks:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/26d7188a-36e8-4672-b25e-2828b7498913/images/03f12269-41f5-43ec-be59-52761718d79d/AA933a.PNG)


  Within the block of six seats occupied by the professor and his students, they can arrange themselves in $6!$ different ways. Let $k$ be the number of possible ways the six people can sit. The total number of arrangements is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  k &= 3 \times 6! \\[11pt]
  &\hspace{-0.8em}\tcbhighmath{k = 2\hspace{0.15em}160}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Let $k$ be the number of possible ways the students can sit at least one seat apart from their professor. We have two cases:
  $\bullet$ If the professor sits at one of the ends, then the students have $6$ seats available to them. There are two possibilities:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/26d7188a-36e8-4672-b25e-2828b7498913/images/3890ae1b-0fd3-4128-a32e-c0076b109530/AA933b.PNG)


  The students can arrange themselves in any order among the six seats. So we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/26d7188a-36e8-4672-b25e-2828b7498913/images/cf3d06b8-66ed-41ee-9e9b-24585ec9619a/AA933d.PNG)


  $\bullet$ If the professor sits in one of the six seats in the middle, the students have only $5$ seats available to them, noting that the five students do not all need to sit together. There are six possible seats where the professor can sit, one example of which is shown here:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/26d7188a-36e8-4672-b25e-2828b7498913/images/87a52a1d-cf0a-4c69-870f-fad4ecca2a84/AA933c.PNG)


  The students can arrange themselves in any order among the five seats. So we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}  
  k_2 &= 6 \times 5! \\[10pt]
  &= 720
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The total will be $k = k_1 + k_2$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  k &= 1\hspace{0.15em}440 + 720 \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{k = 2\hspace{0.15em}160}
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Julie works at a book store and has nine books to display on the main shelf of the store. Four of the books are non-fiction and five are fiction. Each book is different. Determine the number of possible ways Julie can line up the nine books on the main shelf, given that - the non-fiction books should stand together; [2] - the non-fiction books should stand together on either end; [2] - the non-fiction books should stand together and do not stand on either end. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Let $k$ be the number of possible ways that the 9 books can be
ordered with the 4 non-fiction books being arranged together.
  To find $k$, we can consider a two steps process. First, we can
treat the 4 non-fiction books as a single item, and so there are
$6!$ permutations of the 5 fiction books and the block of
non-fiction books. After that, we can arrange the non-fiction books
in $4!$ different ways. Thus, by the multiplication rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k &= 6!\times 4! \hspace{0.3em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 17\hspace{0.15em}280}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $m$ be the number of possible ways that the non-fiction books
can stand together on either end. There are $2$ ways in which the
non-fiction books can be on one end, and $5!$ ways to order the
fiction books next to them. Finally, the non-fiction books can be
ordered in $4!$ ways. Hence, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m &=  2\times 5! \times 4! \hspace{1.0em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 5\hspace{0.15em}760}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $n$ be the number of possible ways that the non-fiction books
can stand together and do not stand on either end.
  Using the results found in parts (a)-(b), we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.8em} n &= k-m \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 11\hspace{0.15em}520}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 11
list.content: A coed soccer team consists of $2$ boys and $3$ girls. They are standing in a line posing for a team picture. Find the number of arrangements such that - All the boys stand next to each other and all the girls stand next to each other. [1] - All the boys stand next to each other. [1] - All the boys are apart and all the girls are apart.[1] - Just the boys are apart. [2]

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Sophia and Zoe compete in a freestyle swimming race where there are no tied finishes and there is a total of $10$ competitors. Find the total number of possible ways in which the ten swimmers can finish if Zoe finishes - in the position immediately after Sophia;[2] - in any position after Sophia.[3]
list.markScheme:
- Let $n$ be the number of possible ways in which Zoe finishes
immediately after Sophia. To find $n$, we can treat Sophia followed
by Zoe as one item. We can then order the 9 items in any order.
Hence, the value of $n$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  n &= 9! \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{= 362\hspace{0.15em}880}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $m$ be the number of possible ways in which Zoe finishes in any
position after Sophia. Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m &= \binom{9}{1}\times8!+\binom{8}{1}\times8!+\binom{7}{1}\times8!+\binom{6}{1}\times8!+\binom{5}{1}\times8!+.....\binom{1}{1}\times8! \\[10pt]
  &= (9 + 8 + 7 + 6 + 5 + \cdots + 1) \times 8!\\[12pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{= 1\hspace{0.15em}814\hspace{0.15em}400}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 13
list.content: Consider the family of polynomials of the form $P(x)=ax^3+bx^2+cx+d$ where coefficients $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ belong to the set $\{2,6,8,24\}$. - Find the number of possible polynomials if - each coefficient value can be repeated; - each coefficient must be different.[4] Consider the case where $P(x)$ has $x+3$ as a factor, two purely imaginary roots, and all the coefficients are different. - - By considering the sum of the roots, find the two possible combinations for coefficients $a$ and $b$. - Show that there is only one way to assign the values $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ if $P(0)=24$.[7] Now, consider the polynomial with the coefficients found in part (b) (ii). - - Express $P(x)$ as a product of one linear and one quadratic factor. - Determine the three roots of $P(x)$.[7]
list.markScheme:
- Let $X$ be the total number of polynomials.
  
  - Given that each coefficient value can be repeated, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    X&=4 \times 4 \times 4 \times 4\\[6pt]
    &=4^4\\[6pt]
    &=256.
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, there are $\tcbhighmath{256}$ possible polynomials if the coefficients can be repeated.
  - Given that each coefficient must be different, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    X&=4!\\[6pt]
    &=4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1\\[6pt]
    &=24.
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, there are $\tcbhighmath{24}$ possible polynomials if each coefficient must be different.

- 
  - Let the roots be $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$. Given that $x+3$ is a factor, $x_1=-3$ is a root. Complex roots occur in conjugate pairs, therefore if the other two roots are imaginary, we have $x_2 = \alpha \mathrm{i}$ and $x_3 = -\alpha \mathrm{i}$, where $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$. Hence, the sum of the roots is given by

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -3 + \alpha \mathrm{i} - \alpha \mathrm{i} \\[6pt]
    &= -3
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Using the formula for the sum of the roots, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -\dfrac{b}{a} \\[6pt]
    -3 &= -\dfrac{b}{a} \\[6pt]
    3a &= b
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We have that $a$ and $b$ belong to the set $\{2,6,8,24\}$ and $3a=b$. Therefore,
    $\tcbhighmath{\text{The two possible combinations are $a=2,\,b=6$ and $a=8,\,b=24$.}}$
  - If $P(0)=24$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    P(0) &= a(0)^3 + b(0)^2 + c(0) + d \\[6pt]
    24 &= d
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The coefficients must all be different. If $d=24$, $b \neq 24$, so we have from part (b)(i) that $a=2$ and $b=6$. Therefore $c=8$.
    $\tcbhighmath{\text{If $P(0)=24$, we must have $a=2,\,b=6,\,c=8$ and $d=24$.}}$

- 
  - Our polynomial is $P(x) = 2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24$. Given that $x+3$ is a factor, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24 &= (x+3)(2x^2 + ex + 8) \\[6pt]
    &= 2x^3 +ex^2 + 8x + 6x^2 +3ex + 24 \\[6pt]
    2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24 &= 2x^3 + (e+6)x^2 + (8+3e)x +24
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Equating the coefficients of $x^2$ and $x$ on the LHS and RHS, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    6 &= e + 6 \\[6pt]
    8 &= 8 + 3e
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We must have $e=0$. Therefore

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    P(x) &= (x+3)(2x^2 + 8) \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-2.1em}\tcbhighmath{P(x) = 2(x+3)(x^2 + 4)}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - We have from part (b)(i) that $x_1=-3$. To find the other two roots, we solve $x^2+4=0$:

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x^2+4&=0 \\[6pt]
    x^2 &= -4 \\[6pt]
    x &= \pm \sqrt{-4} \\[6pt]
    x &= \pm 2\mathrm{i}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    $\tcbhighmath{\text{The roots of } P(x) are x_1=-3,\,x_2=-2\mathrm{i}, and x_3=2\mathrm{i}.}$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
There are $11$ players on a football team who are asked to line up in
one straight line for a team photo. Three of the team members named
Adam, Brad and Chris refuse to stand next to each other. There is no
restriction on the order in which the other team members position
themselves.
Find the number of different orders in which the $11$ team members can
be positioned for the photo.
list.markScheme:
Let $n$ be the number of different orders in which the $11$ team members
can be positioned for the photo. To find $n$, subtract from $11!$ the
number of possible ways to order the $11$ team members such that exactly
two and exactly three of Adam, Brad and Chris stand next to each.

$$
\begin{aligned}
n &= 11! - 8!\times\binom{3}{2}\times2!\times\binom{9}{2}\times2! - 8!\times\binom{3}{3}\times3!\times\binom{9}{1}\times1! \\[6pt]
&= 11! - 8!\times3\times2!\times9\times8 - 8!\times3!\times9 \\[12pt]
&\answer{= 20\hspace{0.15em}321\hspace{0.15em}280}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content: There are six office cubicles arranged in a grid with two rows and three columns as shown in the following diagram. Aria, Bella, Charlotte, Danna, and Emma are to be stationed inside the cubicles to work on various company projects. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/807ae99d-3cec-4f73-82f7-131bf2e1c334/images/e25c512a-e00b-45d6-a7ca-e427bf5fb1dd/AA880_q.png) Find the number of ways of placing the team members in the cubicles in each of the following cases. - Each cubicle is large enough to contain the five team members, but Danna and Emma must not be placed in the same cubicle.[2] - Each cubicle may only contain one team member. But Aria and Bella must not be placed in cubicles which share a boundary, as they tend to get distracted by each other.[5]
list.markScheme:
- We start counting the number of ways we can place each of the team
members. Aria, Bella, Charlotte and Danna can be placed in any of
the six cubicles, but once Danna is placed, Emma can be placed in
the remaining five cubicles. Hence, the total number of ways of
placing the team members in this case is

  $$
  6 \times 6 \times 6 \times 6 \times 5  = \enskip  \answer{6\hspace{0.15em}480}
  $$

- Let's label the cubicles as follows
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/807ae99d-3cec-4f73-82f7-131bf2e1c334/images/afd94baa-58ba-4c02-9ff6-25b8cf1fa7ca/46e01a12bceb8a96908234fb3cd05cae223de337.svg)


  We have several ways of placing Aria and
Bella:
  Aria's cubicleBella's cubicle13, 5, 624, 631, 4, 542, 3, 651, 361, 2, 4
  Thus, there are $16$ ways of placing Aria and Bella in cubicles that
do not share a boundary.
  After that, Charlotte can be placed in any of the 4 remaining
cubicles, Danna in any of the 3 remaining cubicles, and Emma in any
of the 2 remaining cubicles.
  Therefore, the total number of arrangements in this case is

  $$
  16 \times 4 \times 3 \times 2 = \enskip\answer{384}
  $$

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Sophie and Ella play a game. They each have five cards showing roman numerals I, V, X, L, C. Sophie lays her cards face up on the table in order I, V, X, L, C as shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39c87612-7c32-40b7-9150-936d318630c0/images/b4f00281-ba44-44fd-8ba3-6710c101617e/8c2117a8771870dcd1b10ba85dbc123753724df8.svg) Ella shuffles her cards and lays them face down on the table. She then turns them over one by one to see if her card matches with Sophie's card directly above. Sophie wins if no matches occur; otherwise Ella wins. - Show that the probability that Sophie wins the game is $\dfrac{11}{30}$.[6] Sophie and Ella repeat their game so that they play a total of $90$ times. Let the discrete random variable $X$ represent the number of times Sophie wins. - Determine: - the mean of $X$; - the variance of $X$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39c87612-7c32-40b7-9150-936d318630c0/images/ee00d62c-2dc7-40c3-89ae-032bc78b6386/5557f2430f2b6a1d2ae2b382374192f4abd645a4.svg)


  There are $5! = 120$ possible ways to lay down five cards in order
on the table.
  Hence the number of possible ways to lay down five cards with no
matches is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  120 - (45+20+10+0+1) &= 120 - 76 \hspace{1.8em} \\[8pt]
  &= 44\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the probability that Sophie wins the game
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \mathrm{P}(\text{Sophie wins}) &= \dfrac{44}{120} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{11}{30}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Since $X \sim \mathrm{B}(90,11/30)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{E}[X] &= np \\[6pt]
    &= 90\times\dfrac{11}{30} \hspace{3.3em} \\[8pt]
    &\answer{= 33}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the formula for the variance of
$X \sim \mathrm{B}(90,11/30)$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.75em} \mathrm{Var}(X) &= np(1-p) \\[6pt]
    &= 90\times\dfrac{11}{30}\times\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg[1 - \dfrac{11}{30}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 20.9}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
The barcode strings of a new product are created from four letters A, B,
C, D and ten digits $0,1,2,\dots,9$. No three of the letters may be
written consecutively in a barcode string. There is no restriction on
the order in which the numbers can be written.
Find the number of different barcode strings that can be created.
list.markScheme:
Let $n$ denote the number of different barcode strings that can be
created. Four letters and ten digits can be ordered in $14!$ ways. To
find $n$, subtract from $14!$ the number of possible barcode strings
with exactly three and exactly four consecutive letters.

$$
\begin{aligned}
n &= 14! - 10!\times\binom{4}{3}\times3!\times\binom{11}{2}\times2! - 10!\times\binom{4}{4}\times4!\times\binom{11}{1}\times1! \\[6pt]
&= 14! - 10!\times4\times3!\times11\times10 - 10!\times4!\times11 \\[12pt]
&\answer{= 7.66\times10^{10}}\end{aligned}
$$
